case_vignette: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a swollen and painful knee. He says that he was exploring with his friends when he tripped and hit his knee against the ground. He didn't feel like he hit it very hard but it started swelling and becoming very painful. His mom reports that he has always been prone to bleeding from very minor trauma and that others in the family have had similar problems. Based on clinical suspicion a coagulation panel was obtained showing a prothrombin time (PT) of 10 seconds (normal range 9-11 seconds), a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 45 seconds (normal 20-35 seconds), and a normal ristocetin cofactor assay (equivalent to bleeding time). Mixing tests with factor IX and XI do not show complementation, but mixing with factor VIII reverses the coagulation abnormality.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a swollen and painful knee after tripping and hitting it against the ground.
The swelling and pain are persistent.
No, I have not noticed any warmth or redness around my knee.
No, I haven't had any recent injuries or falls other than tripping and hitting my knee.
Yes, I have always been prone to bleeding and swelling from very minor trauma.
Yes, others in my family have had similar problems with bleeding from very minor trauma.

**Final Diagnosis:** Hemorrhagic Knee

This persistent swelling and pain, along with a history of bleeding from minor injuries and a family history of similar symptoms, suggests a hemorrhagic knee, which is a condition characterized by excessive bleeding into the knee joint. This can be caused by various conditions, including bleeding disorders, injuries, or infections. Further evaluation, such as blood tests and imaging studies, may be necessary to determine the underlying cause.

trial_0.vignette_frq: The patient's symptoms and coagulation panel results are consistent with a diagnosis of Hemophilia A.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq:
**Final Diagnosis:** Von Willebrand Disease

(Note: Based on the given symptoms and family history, it is most likely that the patient has Von Willebrand Disease, which is a bleeding disorder characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, a protein involved in the coagulation cascade. Hemophilia A and Hemophilia B are also bleeding disorders, but they are caused by deficiencies in clotting factors VIII and IX, respectively. Bernard-Soulier disease is a platelet disorder, not a bleeding disorder.)
trial_0.multiturn_frq:
**Final Diagnosis:** Hemorrhagic Knee

This diagnosis suggests that the patient may have a bleeding disorder, such as hemophilia or von Willebrand disease, which causes excessive bleeding from even minor injuries. The persistent swelling and pain in the knee, along with a family history of similar symptoms, support this possibility. However, it is important to note that further testing and evaluation by a healthcare professional would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and determine the specific type and severity of the bleeding disorder.

trial_0.singleturn_frq:
